e4: I recommend changing to the new policy because it prioritizes transparency and honesty in financial reporting. Although some investors may be initially caught off guard, the long-term benefits of accuracy and fairness outweigh potential short-term consequences. This change also aligns with ethical business practices and reduces the risk of regulatory issues or damage to the company's reputation. Ultimately, truthful reporting builds trust between the company and its stakeholders.
e5: I would view a reporting policy as ethical if it is transparent, accurate, and unbiased. This means providing stakeholders with timely and comprehensive information that reflects the true financial position of the company. Additionally, an ethical reporting policy should be consistent and free from manipulation to achieve short-term gains or mask underlying issues. Considerations such as fairness to all investors, protection of vulnerable stakeholders, and compliance with regulatory requirements are also essential in evaluating the ethics of a reporting policy.
e6: Yes, I would have several follow-up questions for the management team. What is the proposed timeline for implementing the new policy? How do they plan to communicate the change to investors and stakeholders? What steps will be taken to ensure a smooth transition and minimize potential negative impacts on stock price or investor confidence? Additionally, what measures will be put in place to monitor the effectiveness of the new policy and address any issues that may arise?
